vntrs 0.1.0
  • Reference
  • Changelog
  • GitHub Repository

Identify local and global optima.

explore.Rd

Function that identifies local and global optima via variable neighborhood trust region search (VNTRS).

explore(f, npar, minimize = TRUE, controls = NULL, quiet = TRUE, seed = NULL)

Arguments

f

A function that computes value, gradient, and Hessian of the function to be optimized and returns them as a named list with elements value, gradient, and hessian. It is required that hessian is of class matrix.
npar

The number of parameters of f.
minimize

A boolean, determining whether f should be minimized minimize = TRUE (the default) or maximized minimize = FALSE.
controls

Either NULL or a named list with the following elements. Missing elements are set to default values (printed in parentheses).

  • init_runs (5): The number of short initial searches.

  • init_min (-1): The minimum value for the random initialization.

  • init_max (1): The maximum value for the random initialization.

  • init_iterlim (20): The number of iterations for the short initial searches.

  • neighborhoods (5): The number of nested neighborhoods.

  • neighbors (5): The number of neighbors in each neighborhood.

  • beta (0.05): A non-negative weight factor to account for the function's curvature in the selection of the neighbors. If beta = 0, the curvature is ignored. The higher the value, the higher probability of selecting a neighbor in the direction of the highest function curvature.

  • iterlim (1000): The maximum number of iterations to be performed before the local search is terminated.

  • only_global (FALSE): A boolean. Set only_global = TRUE if you are only interested in the global optimum. In this case, the algorithm will interrupt any local search prematurely that converges to a local optimum. This saves computation time. If only_global = FALSE (the default), the algorithm also looks for local optima.

  • tolerance (1e-5): Passed on to all.equal, which is used to check if two optima are equal.
quiet

Set quiet = FALSE to print progress.
seed

Set a seed for the sampling of the random starting points.

Value

A list of two list,

  • global optima and

  • local optima,

each of which contains lists with

  • value and

  • argument

of each identified optimum.

References

Bierlaire et al. (2009) "A Heuristic for Nonlinear Global Optimization" https://doi.org/10.1287/ijoc.1090.0343

Examples

### Gramacy & Lee function
gramacy_lee = function(x) {
 stopifnot(is.numeric(x))
 stopifnot(length(x) == 1)
 f = expression(sin(10*pi*x) / (2*x) + (x-1)^4)
 g = D(f, "x")
 h = D(g, "x")
 f = eval(f)
 g = eval(g)
 h = eval(h)
 list(value = f, gradient = g, hessian = as.matrix(h))
}
explore(f = gramacy_lee, npar = 1, seed = 1)

#> Error in explore(f = gramacy_lee, npar = 1, seed = 1): could not find function "explore"

### Shubert function
shubert = function(x) {
 stopifnot(is.numeric(x))
 stopifnot(length(x) == 2)
 f = expression(
   (cos(2*x1+1) + 2*cos(3*x1+2) + 3*cos(4*x1+3) + 4*cos(5*x1+4) +
   5*cos(6*x1+5)) *
   (cos(2*x2+1) + 2*cos(3*x2+2) + 3*cos(4*x2+3) + 4*cos(5*x2+4) +
   5*cos(6*x2+5))
 )
 g1 = D(f, "x1")
 g2 = D(f, "x2")
 h11 = D(g1, "x1")
 h12 = D(g1, "x2")
 h22 = D(g2, "x2")
 x1 = x[1]
 x2 = x[2]
 f = eval(f)
 g = c(eval(g1), eval(g2))
 h = rbind(c(eval(h11), eval(h12)), c(eval(h12), eval(h22)))
 list(value = f, gradient = g, hessian = h)
}
explore(f = shubert, npar = 2, seed = 1)

#> Error in explore(f = shubert, npar = 2, seed = 1): could not find function "explore"

### Rosenbrock function
rosenbrock = function(x) {
  stopifnot(is.numeric(x))
  stopifnot(length(x) == 2)
  f = expression(100 * (x2 - x1^2)^2 + (1 - x1)^2)
  g1 = D(f, "x1")
  g2 = D(f, "x2")
  h11 = D(g1, "x1")
  h12 = D(g1, "x2")
  h22 = D(g2, "x2")
  x1 = x[1]
  x2 = x[2]
  f = eval(f)
  g = c(eval(g1), eval(g2))
  h = rbind(c(eval(h11), eval(h12)), c(eval(h12), eval(h22)))
  list(value = f, gradient = g, hessian = h)
}
explore(f = rosenbrock, npar = 2, seed = 1)

#> Error in explore(f = rosenbrock, npar = 2, seed = 1): could not find function "explore"
